TextView.android:text: The Role Water Plays in Skin Health

Drinking an adequate amount of water daily is important for overall good health. Water aids in digestion, circulation, absorption and even rids the body and skin of toxins. Not everyone will agree that water consumption will improve skin… but it certainly can’t hurt. Many people often report that by increasing their water intake, their skin has a more radiant glow. Those who suffer from acne have reported the same results.

A 2007 study in the International Journal of Cosmetic Science took an in-depth look at the effects of long-term water intake on skin health. The study found that drinking 2.25 liters (9.5 cups) of water every day for four weeks altered skin density and thickness. A second study from the University of Missouri-Columbia showed that drinking 500 milliliters of water (about two cups) increased blood flow to the skin.
Protect yourself from the sun

One of the most important ways to take care of your skin is to protect it from the sun. A lifetime of sun exposure can cause wrinkles, age spots and other skin problems — as well as increase the risk of skin cancer.
For the most complete sun protection:
*Use sunscreen. Use a broad-spectrum sunscreen with an SPF of at least 15. Apply sunscreen generously, and reapply every two hours — or more often if you're swimming or perspiring.
*Seek shade. Avoid the sun between 10 a.m. and 4 p.m., when the sun's rays are strongest.

*Wear protective clothing. Cover your skin with tightly woven long-sleeved shirts, long pants and wide-brimmed hats. Also consider laundry additives, which give clothing an additional layer of ultraviolet protection for a certain number of washings, or special sun-protective clothing — which is specifically designed to block ultraviolet rays.

Body itching when sleeping
The causes of body itching when sleeping include many factors and influences, the following are the most important:
Daily systems

Natural changes in the circadian rhythm, or circadian rhythm, may be the most common cause of itching during sleep, as they affect functions of the skin, such as temperature regulation, fluid balance, skin moisture, and hormonal fluctuations. These changes include: follows:

*Body temperature: The hypothalamus, or hypothalamus, maintains the daily rhythms. The hypothalamus is an essential gland in the brain responsible for regulating body temperature. The body temperature reaches its highest level in the late evening, while it reaches its lowest level in the early morning. The hypothalamus cools the body during NREM sleep, or directly when sleep begins. More blood flows to the skin, and the body releases heat to the surrounding environment during this stage. Which increases the temperature of the skin and causes the sensation of itching at night.

*Skin dryness: One of the causes of itching during sleep is increased skin loss of moisture throughout the night, a process called transepidermal water loss and dehydration, so the skin's barrier function decreases during the night, which may allow the entry of itch-inducing substances at night. Damage to the outer layer of skin (stratum corneum) due to xerosis or atopic dermatitis increases pathological itching, especially at night.

*Hormone fluctuations: Cortisol secretion follows a circadian rhythm, with its concentrations lowest during the evening and around midnight; So its anti-inflammatory effects are minimal. Which may cause itching of the body before bedtime and throughout the night.

*Cytokines: The body's secretion of some substances varies according to the time of day to night, as the secretion of cytokines increases during the night, resulting in stimulation of inflammation and itching when sleeping.
Getting old

*Aging is one of the causes of body itching when sleeping, as some natural factors of aging contribute to the feeling of itching at night, such as dry skin and a decrease in the body's immunity, and neurodegeneration increases skin irritation and itching.
Insect bites
Insect bites are among the causes of body itching at bedtime, the most disturbing and insomnia, and examples of these insects are:

*Bed bugs and fleas: They are nocturnal insects that feed on blood, and insect bites should be excluded in all cases of itching, as it is easy to see noticeable bite marks on the skin that improve within a few hours or days. Insect bites may cause a mild allergic reaction and the area of redness and inflammation of the skin becomes larger and may improve within a week.

*Scabies: It is a skin disease that causes itching due to the mite insect. Scabies is one of the causes of body itching when sleeping and may affect all ages. Itching is usually present all the time but is often more noticeable when sleeping due to its nocturnal nature.
Polycythemia vera

*Itching is a common symptom of polycythemia, a condition in which the bone marrow produces too many red blood cells, white blood cells, and platelets. Many patients with this condition experience itching, especially after showering or getting the skin wet. Many people have to shower in the evening before bed, which increases the chances of itching at night.
Inflammatory skin diseases
The causes of body itching when sleeping may be attributed to some common skin disorders, including:

*Atopic dermatitis or eczema: Atopic dermatitis is a chronic skin condition in which sufferers have difficulty falling asleep and waking up early due to body itching at bedtime that leads to fatigue and insomnia.

*Psoriasis: A chronic, inflammatory, autoimmune skin disorder characterized by scaly patches of skin, covering the body and scalp. A thermoregulatory imbalance that makes the skin warm during the first few hours of sleep also contributes to the condition. Which causes increased body itching when sleeping and discomfort.
*Lichen planus is another autoimmune disease that often appears inside the mouth as well as many other parts of the body, nails, and scalp. It appears as a purple, flat-topped, itchy rash.
It should be noted that excessive itching and scratching, regardless of the cause, may lead to further irritation or skin patches called lichen simplex chronica.
The most common causes of bedtime itch in children are atopic dermatitis and psoriasis with lichen simplex chronicus, as well as prurigo nodosum.
